string.text: The 12.7x55 is a subsonic round used primarily by the VKS Vykhlop. Its large size in combination with its ability to be fired over a great distance means that it delivers a massive amount of kinetic energy when impacting with a target.

The armour piercing variant of this round boasts light anti-material capabilities, able to penetrate armour to a greater extent than what would be expected from the 9x19 round it was designed to replace.
Originally created for the FN P90 and FN Five-seven, the 5.7x28 round is a small-calibre, high-velocity cartridge designed in response to NATO requests for a replacement for the ageing 9x19.

More commonly known as the .50 BMG, the 12.7x99 round was developed at some point in the late 1910s and is effectively a greatly scaled up version of the 7.62x63 round. Over the years it has found itself being used by heavy machine guns during World War II and by anti-material sniper rifles in the modern day.
The 7.62x25 Tokarev is a bottle-necked pistol cartridge widely used in former Soviet Union and its satellite states. The cartridge has largely been replaced in most capacities by the 9x18.
A steel-core variant of the standard 7.62x25 round allowing for much greater penetration when fired at soft targets.

A steel-core variant of the standard 7.62x39 round, as if it wasn't powerful enough already, a weapon firing this round will be able to punch even harder through tough materials and will decimate lightly armoured soft targets.

The 7.62x39 round is a rifle cartridge of Soviet origin that was designed during World War II. Due to its use in, and the the worldwide proliferation of Kalashnikov pattern rifles, the cartridge is used by both militaries and civilians alike and is extremely common.
An armour piercing variant of the standard round, it uses a hardened steel-core to give the round increased penetration.
The 7.62x51 round is a rimless bottlenecked rifle cartridge developed in the 1950s as a standard for small arms among NATO countries until it was largely superseded by the 5.56x45 round.
7.62-calibre high precision armour-piercing sniper rounds. Typically used with the SVD and SVU sniper rifles.

The 8.6x70 round, also known as the .338 Lapua Magnum, is a rimless, bottlenecked, centerfire rifle cartridge. It serves as both an anti-personnel and anti-material round for sniper rifles. However its anti-material capabilities are hindered by its low kinetic energy.

Fragmentation warhead for anti-personnel warfare used with the RPG-7 grenade launcher. The main purpose of the warhead is to kill enemies in cover outside the range of hand grenades using the RPG-7 launcher.
Cheap 7.62 calibre machine gun round. Its design makes it unsuitable for sniper rifles, so it is used only with the PKM machine gun.
Regular fragmentation grenade for the GP-25 Kostyor under-barrel grenade launcher.
40 mm grenade for the M203 under-barrel grenade launcher. This round has a 5 meter kill zone.
